awd_titl_txt: Element: Data: HDR: Enabling data interoperability for NSF archives of high-rate real-time GPS and seismic observations of induced earthquakes and structural damage detection in OK
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent studies have identified critical differences between earthquakes induced by wastewater injection in tectonically passive regions of oil and gas exploration (such as earthquakes recently experienced in Oklahoma, Texas, and Kansas) and earthquakes in tectonically active environments (such as fault zones in California).  This has significant implications for earthquake engineering in the Midwest, where the building inventory was not designed to withstand large earthquakes or cumulative damage due to successive earthquakes.  Estimating the level of ground shaking at different frequencies is needed to calculate structural response, understand which structures run higher risks of earthquake damage, and establish criteria for building design and real-time decision making. 
 
This project uses recent breakthroughs in real-time GPS data analysis to address challenges limiting the use of real-time GPS and seismic data by the geoscience and engineering communities.  The effort develops new capabilities to handle data streams in a manner that is independent of the content and formats of the environmental sensor measurements.  Creating these links will have a substantial impact on interoperability among the geodesy, seismology, and earthquake engineering research communities.  The project demonstrates the approach using multi-sensor geoscience and engineering datasets recorded on structures on the Oklahoma State University campus and in the field near the location of the Magnitude 5.8 September 2016 Pawnee earthquake.  The effort creates new methods for capturing permanent deformation in structures, and a better understanding of building inventory resiliency.

This award by the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is jointly supported by the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

por.por_cntn:
Monitoring structural performance remains a challenge for the engineering community. For a state like Oklahoma, whose aging infrastructure has been unusually stressed from induced seismicity since 2011, structural monitoring is even more vital. This research allowed development of a cyberinfrastructure that would allow transmission of engineering and geoscientific data on the same platform and thus simultaneously obtain low frequency and permanent deformation measurements of ground motion and building response. The cyberinfrastructure was tested on a vulnerable multi-story dormitory on Oklahoma State University's (OSU’s) campus. The structure was instrumented with an accelerometer and a gyroscope each on the lowermost and the uppermost floors. A rooftop GPS was also installed for static deformation. 

 

In addition to developing the cyberinfrastructure, an algorithm for fragility modeling using the recorded data was also developed. During our 14 months of monitoring, a number of earthquakes were recorded, the largest being a Mw 4.8 event with epicenter in Covington, Oklahoma, 47 km northwest of Stillwater. The Covington earthquake was used for demonstrating the fragility algorithm, which was a combination of deterministic (Finite Elements) and statistical (Neural Network and fragility) modeling. In essence, the algorithm used the lower and upper accelerometer responses respectively as inputs and outputs of the building’s transfer function that was iteratively determined. The work is being extended to include the lower and upper gyro responses as well, constraining all six-degrees of motion. Feasibility of near-real time monitoring of the static deformation was assessed. Results showed real-time monitoring of static deformation with an accuracy of 10 cm and bias of up to 4 cm. Monitoring for the purpose of response and recovery with a delay of 2 weeks provided the highest accuracy of 1 cm and bias less than 5 mm, which would provide owners useful information for reoccupancy.

 

The project offered unmatched workforce training opportunities that were only possible through this fruitful collaboration between researchers in geosciences, civil engineering, and cyberinfrastructure. Training opportunities covered sensor installation, data collection and interpretation, remote sensor communication, earthquake analysis and simulation, structural assessment, probabilistic modeling, numerical simulations, coding, artificial neural networks, and other machine learning and data science approaches. The project supported several researchers in UCSD and OSU including undergraduate, and M.Sc. and Ph.D. graduate students, as well as post-doctoral researchers. Several of the mentees belonged to underrepresented minorities in STEM fields. 

 

Another significant outcome was the opening of a lab-to-market pathway for the research product as a system for automated structural damage diagnosis and prognosis. It is currently being commercialized under the brand name “INTACT.” The founding team, Jaiswal and Soliman, were a part of the 2023 first fall National I-Corps cohort (Award Number: 2317197, - Seismic Fragility Monitoring and Estimation System). In their effort to commercialize the system, the team has already conducted 107 customer discovery interviews learning about the pain points of owners and operators of various kinds of structures and testing their hypotheses about how INTACT can or cannot satisfy their monitoring needs.


 

 


Last Modified: 04/25/2024
Modified by: Jennifer S Haase

Image
  • (a) Oklahoma State University Kerr-Drummond Hall (view to the east, Kerr building on the left). (b) GNSS antenna on the roof of Kerr Hall. (c) Trimble NET-RS GNSS receiver (d) Kinemetrics Etna-2 strong-motion accelerometer in the rooftop stairwell. Another Etna-2 is installed on the first floor.
    Jennifer Haase
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jennifer S Haase
